content.description:
ESTIMATED INFANT MORTALITY RATES IN WESTERN EUROPE AS A PERCENTAGE OF LIVE BIRTHS

Pre-1750
 1740–1790
 1780–1820

England
 18.7
 16.1
 12.2

France
 25.2
 21.3
 19.5

Spain
 28.1
 27.3
 22.0

Switzerland
 28.3
 23.7
 25.5

Sweden
 NA
 22.5
 18.7

Source: Adapted from Michael Flinn, The European Demographic System, 1500–1820, Johns Hopkins University Press, 1981, table 6.9, p. 92.

The data in the table were derived from an analysis of parish church records in the various countries.
content.question: Which of the following most strongly contributed to the overall trend shown in the table?

choices.label: The growth of a consumer economy centered on production of items for domestic use
Improvements in agricultural productivity and food-distribution capability
Large-scale migration of Europeans to overseas colonies
The spread of Enlightenment ideas concerning the natural sciences

content.answer: Improvements in agricultural productivity and food-distribution capability

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Explain a historical concept, development, or process.
